heroHeader.en: Get real-time updates on the weather conditions on the red planet, with data sourced directly from NASA's Curiosity Rover.

solNumber.en: A Martian sol (short for 'solar day') is the equivalent of a day on Mars, which is slightly longer than a day on Earth. The number displayed here is the number of solar days since the start of Curiosity's mission.

latestUpdateDate.en: The date of the latest update from Curiosity. Data is usually fetched every 3-7 days. Update frequency varies depending on the capacity of NASA's Deep Space Network.

season.en: Mars has four seasons just like Earth, but they last about twice as long. That's because it takes about two Earth years for Mars to go around the Sun.

marsDate.en: Earth date converted to Darian Calendar. The year is divided into 24 months. Each month has 4 weeks. Each week has 7 days: Sol, Luna, Mars, Mercurius, Jupiter, Venus, Saturnus.

airAverageTemperature.en: Mast sensor data. Mast sensor is installed 2,20m above ground. Mars atmosphere is extremely thin, so the temperature tends to drop sharply with elevation. The temperature shown here is the calculated avarage of highest and lowest temperature recorded during the last sol. Scroll down for more detailed measurements.

groundAverageTemperature.en: Ground level sensor data. Mars atmosphere is extremely thin, so the temperature tends to drop sharply with elevation. The temperature shown here is the calculated avarage of highest and lowest temperature recorded during the last sol. Scroll down for more detailed measurements.

atmoOpacity.en: Visibility conditions in Martian atmosphere. Apart from the usual 'Sunny' days Mars atmosphere conditions can be influenced by dust storms or clouds of water ice.

pressure.en: The atmospheric pressure on Mars is much lower than Earth's. The average surface pressure on Mars is about 6.1 millibars (0.087 psi), which is only about 1% of Earth's atmospheric pressure at sea level.

localUvIndex.en: The surface of Mars is exposed to high levels of ultraviolet (UV) radiation from the Sun. This is because Mars has a much thinner atmosphere than Earth, which means that there is less protection from the Sun's harmful UV rays.

sunrise.en: The timing of sunrise and sunset on Mars changes significantly throughout the Martian year. During the Martian summer, the sun can be up for as long as 24.6 hours at the equator, while during the Martian winter, the sun may only be up for 4.7 hours at the poles.

sunset.en: The timing of sunrise and sunset on Mars changes significantly throughout the Martian year. During the Martian summer, the sun can be up for as long as 24.6 hours at the equator, while during the Martian winter, the sun may only be up for 4.7 hours at the poles.

lowestTempRecorded.en: The lowest temperature recorded during sol.

highestTempRecorded.en: The highest temperature recorded during sol.

solarLongitude.en: Solar longitude on Mars is a measure of the position of the planet in its orbit around the Sun, expressed in degrees. It is often used by scientists to track seasonal changes on the planet and to coordinate observations by spacecraft and rovers.

tempAmplitude.en: Select range of dates and analyze the fluctuations in temperature measurements.
